title: Graphical Approach for Multiple Comparison Procedures
text: base object graphicalMCP initial_graph, weighted, directed graph represented matrix transition (edge) weights, vector hypothesis (vertex) weights.
code: library(graphicalMCP)  # A graphical multiple comparison procedure with two primary hypotheses (H1 # and H2) and two secondary hypotheses (H3 and H4) # See Figure 1 in Bretz, F., Posch, M., Glimm, E., Klinglmueller, F., Maurer, # W., & Rohmeyer, K. (2011). Graphical approaches for multiple comparison # procedures using weighted Bonferroni, Simes, or parametric tests. Biometrical # Journal, 53(6), 894-913. hypotheses <- c(0.5, 0.5, 0, 0) transitions <- rbind(   c(0, 0, 1, 0),   c(0, 0, 0, 1),   c(0, 1, 0, 0),   c(1, 0, 0, 0) ) names <- c("A1", "A2", "B1", "B2") g_dose <- create_graph(hypotheses, transitions, names)  g_dose #> An initial graph #>  #> --- Hypothesis weights --- #> A1: 0.5000 #> A2: 0.5000 #> B1: 0.0000 #> B2: 0.0000 #>  #> --- Transition weights --- #>        A1     A2     B1     B2 #> A1 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 #> A2 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 #> B1 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 #> B2 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000

title: Graphical Approach for Multiple Comparison Procedures
text: mixture statistical tests supported graphicalMCP. graph can tested given alpha test_graph(). report generated, showing graph & test results. example, weighted Bonferroni test applied hypotheses, threshold 0.05. can reject given intersection hypothesis individual hypotheses within sub-graph passes test assigned . can reject hypothesis globally intersection hypotheses containing hypothesis rejected. instance, example can reject every intersection hypothesis except one containing B1 & B2 (Row 3 test_results). Thus, can reject null hypotheses A1 & A2, reject null hypotheses B1 & B2. Simes parametric testing methods also supported, using test_types argument. Try setting verbose critical flags detailed report testing.

title: Graphical Approach for Multiple Comparison Procedures
text: methods originally implemented R 2011 paper gMCP package, still available CRAN today: install.packages("gMCP") https://github.com/kornl/gMCP However, development ceased original package, hope re-implement methods clearer distinction weighting procedures test procedures; fewer dependencies, particular shedding Java dependency; simpler, transparent S3 class framework; improvements accuracy parametric Simes test methods. portion Simes testing also implemented lrstat package (install.packages("lrstat")) similar speed graphicalMCP.

title: Test hypotheses with the critical values method — bonferroni_test_vals
code: w <- c(H1 = .5, H2 = .5, H3 = 0, H4 = 0)  p <- c(.024, .01, .026, .027)  graphicalMCP:::bonferroni_test_vals(p, w, .05) #>    intersection hypothesis       test     p <= c *   w * alpha   res #> H1           NA         H1 bonferroni 0.024 <=     0.5 *  0.05  TRUE #> H2           NA         H2 bonferroni 0.010 <=     0.5 *  0.05  TRUE #> H3           NA         H3 bonferroni 0.026 <=     0.0 *  0.05 FALSE #> H4           NA         H4 bonferroni 0.027 <=     0.0 *  0.05 FALSE graphicalMCP:::parametric_test_vals(p, w, .05, diag(4)) #>    intersection hypothesis       test     p <=        c *   w * alpha   res #> H1           NA         H1 parametric 0.024 <= 1.012823 * 0.5 *  0.05  TRUE #> H2           NA         H2 parametric 0.010 <= 1.012823 * 0.5 *  0.05  TRUE #> H3           NA         H3 parametric 0.026 <= 1.012823 * 0.0 *  0.05 FALSE #> H4           NA         H4 parametric 0.027 <= 1.012823 * 0.0 *  0.05 FALSE graphicalMCP:::simes_test_vals(p, w, .05) #>   intersection hypothesis  test     p <= c *   w * alpha  res #> 1           NA         H1 simes 0.024 <=     1.0 *  0.05 TRUE #> 2           NA         H2 simes 0.010 <=     0.5 *  0.05 TRUE #> 3           NA         H3 simes 0.026 <=     1.0 *  0.05 TRUE #> 4           NA         H4 simes 0.027 <=     1.0 *  0.05 TRUE

title: Obtain hypothesis rejection probabilities — calculate_power
code: calculate_power(   graph,   alpha = 0.05,   test_groups = list(seq_along(graph$hypotheses)),   test_types = c("bonferroni"),   test_corr = NULL,   sim_n = 100,   marginal_power = rep(0, length(graph$hypotheses)),   sim_corr = diag(length(graph$hypotheses)),   sim_success = 1:2,   sim_seed = NULL,   force_closure = FALSE )

title: Obtain hypothesis rejection probabilities — calculate_power
text: graph initial graph returned create_graph() alpha numeric scalar specifying global significance level testing test_groups list numeric vectors specifying hypotheses test together test_types character vector tests apply given groups test_corr Optional test_types parametric. numeric matrix correlations hypotheses' test statistics sim_n integer scalar specifying many simulations run marginal_power numeric vector mean values use simulating p-values. Exactly one mean per hypothesis needed, p-values sampled multivariate normal distribution. See Details sim_corr numeric matrix correlations hypotheses used sample multivariate normal distribution generate p-values sim_success numeric vector indicating hypotheses can rejected consider experiment success (One must rejected, necessarily ). can range single hypothesis hypotheses graph sim_seed (Optional) Random seed set simulating p-values. Set use consistent set p simulations across power calculations force_closure logical scalar used determine whether full closure test used Bonferroni testing. Ignored tests non-Bonferroni

title: Obtain hypothesis rejection probabilities — calculate_power
text: list five elements power_local - rejection proportion hypothesis individually power_expected - average number hypotheses rejected single simulation power_at_least_1 - proportion simulations reject hypothesis power_all - proportion simulations reject hypotheses power_success - proportion simulations reject hypotheses specified sim_success

title: Obtain hypothesis rejection probabilities — calculate_power
text: parameters normal distribution set marginal_power (means) sim_corr (correlation test statistics). mean hypothesis set marginal power $$d_i=P_{\xi_i}(p_i\leq\alpha)$$ \(\xi_i\) non-centrality parameter. correlation test statistics induced study design.

title: Define a graph representing a multiple comparison procedure — create_graph
text: hypotheses numeric vector hypothesis weights initial graphical multiple comparison procedure. Must vector values 0 & 1 (inclusive). length match row column lengths transitions. sum hypothesis weights exceed 1 transitions numeric matrix transition weights hypotheses initial graphical multiple comparison procedure. Must square matrix values 0 & 1 (inclusive). row column lengths match length hypotheses. row (Transition weights leaving hypothesis) can sum 1. diagonal (Transition weights hypothesis ) must 0s names (Optional) character vector hypothesis names. provided, names hypotheses transitions used. names specified, hypotheses named sequentially H1, H2, ...

title: Define a graph representing a multiple comparison procedure — create_graph
code: # A graphical multiple comparison procedure with two primary hypotheses (H1 # and H2) and two secondary hypotheses (H3 and H4) # See Figure 1 in Bretz, F., Posch, M., Glimm, E., Klinglmueller, F., Maurer, # W., & Rohmeyer, K. (2011). Graphical approaches for multiple comparison # procedures using weighted Bonferroni, Simes, or parametric tests. # Biometrical Journal, 53(6), 894-913. hypotheses <- c(0.5, 0.5, 0, 0) transitions <- rbind(   c(0, 0, 1, 0),   c(0, 0, 0, 1),   c(0, 1, 0, 0),   c(1, 0, 0, 0) ) names <- c("H1", "H2", "H3", "H4") g <- create_graph(hypotheses, transitions, names) g #> An initial graph #>  #> --- Hypothesis weights --- #> H1: 0.5000 #> H2: 0.5000 #> H3: 0.0000 #> H4: 0.0000 #>  #> --- Transition weights --- #>        H1     H2     H3     H4 #> H1 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 #> H2 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 #> H3 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 #> H4 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000  # Explicit names override names in `hypotheses` (with a warning) hypotheses <- c(h1 = 0.5, h2 = 0.5, h3 = 0, h4 = 0) transitions <- rbind(   c(0, 0, 1, 0),   c(0, 0, 0, 1),   c(0, 1, 0, 0),   c(1, 0, 0, 0) ) names <- c("H1", "H2", "H3", "H4") g <- create_graph(hypotheses, transitions, names) #> Warning: hypothesis names specified - overriding names in #>                     'hypotheses' and 'transitions' g #> An initial graph #>  #> --- Hypothesis weights --- #> H1: 0.5000 #> H2: 0.5000 #> H3: 0.0000 #> H4: 0.0000 #>  #> --- Transition weights --- #>        H1     H2     H3     H4 #> H1 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 #> H2 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 #> H3 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 #> H4 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000  # Explicit names override names in `transitions` (with a warning) hypotheses <- c(0.5, 0.5, 0, 0) transitions <- rbind(   h1 = c(0, 0, 1, 0),   h2 = c(0, 0, 0, 1),   h3 = c(0, 1, 0, 0),   h4 = c(1, 0, 0, 0) ) names <- c("H1", "H2", "H3", "H4") g <- create_graph(hypotheses, transitions, names) #> Warning: hypothesis names specified - overriding names in #>                     'hypotheses' and 'transitions' g #> An initial graph #>  #> --- Hypothesis weights --- #> H1: 0.5000 #> H2: 0.5000 #> H3: 0.0000 #> H4: 0.0000 #>  #> --- Transition weights --- #>        H1     H2     H3     H4 #> H1 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 #> H2 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 #> H3 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 #> H4 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000  # Use names in `hypotheses` hypotheses <- c(H1 = 0.5, H2 = 0.5, H3 = 0, H4 = 0) transitions <- rbind(   c(0, 0, 1, 0),   c(0, 0, 0, 1),   c(0, 1, 0, 0),   c(1, 0, 0, 0) ) g <- create_graph(hypotheses, transitions) g #> An initial graph #>  #> --- Hypothesis weights --- #> H1: 0.5000 #> H2: 0.5000 #> H3: 0.0000 #> H4: 0.0000 #>  #> --- Transition weights --- #>        H1     H2     H3     H4 #> H1 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 #> H2 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 #> H3 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 #> H4 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000  # Use names in `transitions` hypotheses <- c(0.5, 0.5, 0, 0) transitions <- rbind(   H1 = c(0, 0, 1, 0),   H2 = c(0, 0, 0, 1),   H3 = c(0, 1, 0, 0),   H4 = c(1, 0, 0, 0) ) g <- create_graph(hypotheses, transitions) g #> An initial graph #>  #> --- Hypothesis weights --- #> H1: 0.5000 #> H2: 0.5000 #> H3: 0.0000 #> H4: 0.0000 #>  #> --- Transition weights --- #>        H1     H2     H3     H4 #> H1 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 #> H2 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 #> H3 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 #> H4 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000  # When names are not specified, hypotheses are numbered sequentially as # H1, H2, ... hypotheses <- c(0.5, 0.5, 0, 0) transitions <- rbind(   c(0, 0, 1, 0),   c(0, 0, 0, 1),   c(0, 1, 0, 0),   c(1, 0, 0, 0) ) g <- create_graph(hypotheses, transitions) g #> An initial graph #>  #> --- Hypothesis weights --- #> H1: 0.5000 #> H2: 0.5000 #> H3: 0.0000 #> H4: 0.0000 #>  #> --- Transition weights --- #>        H1     H2     H3     H4 #> H1 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 #> H2 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 #> H3 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 #> H4 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000

title: Calculate adjusted p-values — p_adjust_bonferroni
code: set.seed(22723)  w <- c("H1" = .75, "H2" = .25, "H3" = 0) p <- c("H1" = .019, "H2" = .025, "H3" = .05)  graphicalMCP:::p_adjust_bonferroni(p, w) #> [1] 0.02533333 graphicalMCP:::p_adjust_simes(p, w) #> [1] 0.025  corr1 <- diag(3) corr2 <- corr1 corr2[lower.tri(corr2)] <- corr2[upper.tri(corr2)] <- runif(3, -1, 1)  # No correlation graphicalMCP:::p_adjust_parametric(p, w, corr1) #> [1] 0.025213  # Uniform random pairwise correlations graphicalMCP:::p_adjust_parametric(p, w, corr2) #> [1] 0.02196006

code: par_gate <- simple_successive_1() graph_size <- length(par_gate$hypotheses)  p <- c(.001, .02, .002, .03)  weights <- generate_weights(par_gate) inter_h <- weights[, seq_len(graph_size), drop = FALSE] compact_weights <- ifelse(   inter_h,   weights[, seq_len(graph_size) + graph_size, drop = FALSE],   NA ) compact_weights[is.na(compact_weights)] <- 0  graphicalMCP:::test_graph_fast(p, .025, compact_weights, inter_h) #> [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE graphicalMCP:::bonferroni_sequential_cpp(par_gate, p, .025) #> [1] 1 1 1 0

title: Report details of hypothesis rejections — bonferroni_sequential
code: hypotheses <- c(0.5, 0.5, 0, 0) transitions <- rbind(   c(0, 0, 1, 0),   c(0, 0, 0, 1),   c(0, 1, 0, 0),   c(1, 0, 0, 0) )  g <- create_graph(hypotheses, transitions) p <- c(.01, .005, .015, .022)  corr <- matrix(nrow = 4, ncol = 4) corr[3:4, 3:4] <- .9 diag(corr) <- 1  corr2 <- matrix(.5, nrow = 4, ncol = 4) diag(corr2) <- 1  # The default is all Bonferroni with alpha = .05 test_graph(g, p) #>  #> Test parameters ---------------------------------------------------------------- #>   An initial graph #>    #>   --- Hypothesis weights --- #>   H1: 0.5000 #>   H2: 0.5000 #>   H3: 0.0000 #>   H4: 0.0000 #>    #>   --- Transition weights --- #>          H1     H2     H3     H4 #>   H1 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 #>   H2 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 #>   H3 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 #>   H4 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 #>  #>   Global alpha = 0.05 #>  #>                          H1    H2    H3    H4 #>   Unadjusted p-values: 0.01 0.005 0.015 0.022 #>  #>   Test types #>   bonferroni: (H1-H2-H3-H4) #>  #> Global test summary ------------------------------------------------------------ #>   Hypothesis Adj. P-value Reject #>           H1         0.02   TRUE #>           H2         0.01   TRUE #>           H3         0.03   TRUE #>           H4         0.03   TRUE  # But tests can be specified at the hypothesis-level test_graph(   graph = g,   p = p,   alpha = .025,   groups = list(1, 2, 3:4),   test_types = c("bonferroni", "simes", "parametric"),   corr = corr ) #>  #> Test parameters ---------------------------------------------------------------- #>   An initial graph #>    #>   --- Hypothesis weights --- #>   H1: 0.5000 #>   H2: 0.5000 #>   H3: 0.0000 #>   H4: 0.0000 #>    #>   --- Transition weights --- #>          H1     H2     H3     H4 #>   H1 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 #>   H2 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 1.0000 #>   H3 0.0000 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 #>   H4 1.0000 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 #>  #>   Global alpha = 0.025 #>  #>                          H1    H2    H3    H4 #>   Unadjusted p-values: 0.01 0.005 0.015 0.022 #>  #>   Correlation matrix:    H1 H2  H3  H4 #>                       H1  1 NA  NA  NA #>                       H2 NA  1  NA  NA #>                       H3 NA NA 1.0 0.9 #>                       H4 NA NA 0.9 1.0 #>  #>   Test types #>   bonferroni: (H1) #>        simes: (H2) #>   parametric: (H3-H4) #>  #> Global test summary ------------------------------------------------------------ #>   Hypothesis Adj.
